discoveries.content: Input workflow: folder of video files + transcript to match. Source videos often from YouTube (user-owned).
May need initial processing phase to generate transcripts for all source videos before matching can begin.
Word/phrase clip dictionary approach - pre-cut clips organized by word/phrase for reuse across projects.
Prefer not reusing clips from the same source video multiple times in a single output project.
Output clip naming: source video filename + clip identifier suffix for traceability.
Phrases sometimes work better than individual words - selection is context-dependent on the target music video.
Clip dictionary organized by 'brand' (e.g., a conference). Dictionary persists across multiple song projects within same brand.
Multiple brands supported - each brand has its own separate clip library that can be used for multiple songs.
Phrase boundaries are manually curated, not auto-detected. Phrases requested on-demand when a song project needs them.
Dictionary building is lyrics-driven: feed in target lyrics, use that as basis for what words/phrases to extract from source videos.
Search interface needed: 'source the phrase X from the video library in brand Y' - search across sources for specific phrases.
Match selection is human-in-the-loop: phonetic quality matching is nice-to-have, but final selection is manual. Visual quality not a factor.
Highlights Mode: batch processing of 30+ videos after a conference event to generate scheduled social content.
Target platforms: YouTube and LinkedIn. Output needs portrait format conversion for shorts/reels.
Portrait conversion can use fixed crop area since speakers typically in fixed location - simpler than full visual tracking.
Highlights input includes session description alongside video - used to identify hooks and insightful moments.
Highlight selection goals: (1) hook viewers into watching full video, OR (2) deliver standalone insightful knowledge snippet.
Highlights output: clip file + title/hook text. Title for YouTube, post content for LinkedIn.
On-screen captions essential, especially for LinkedIn. Must be burned into video.
Caption enhancement: inject brand-specific emojis/logos when certain terms mentioned (e.g., Kubernetes logo when 'Kubernetes' spoken).
Brand-specific emoji/icon/logo mapping: user-curated list per brand. Different conferences have different visual assets.
CLI tool interface - no web UI or desktop app needed.
Clip output: dump candidates to folder for manual review in video editor. Search interface outputs to folder too.
Save/resume project state needed, though most work is batch processed.
Idempotent processing: if cataloguing/transcribing is interrupted (even mid-video), it can be resumed without re-doing completed work.
Failure tolerant for unreliable internet - network issues shouldn't corrupt state or lose progress.
Storage format: no preference - use whatever is best for the use case. Human-readability not required. Portability not needed independently (entire project shared together).
Keep full transcripts and source videos for future reuse. Extracted clips stored separately. Both retained to support creating new outputs from same source material.
Videos referenced where they live. User copies videos into project. Suggested structure: brand/source/ for source video storage.
Preference for free/cheap transcription. Speed not priority if pause/resume works - can run overnight/weekend. Typical workload: 30-35 videos x 30min = 15-20 hours content.
Need cost/time estimation before processing. Acceptable threshold ~$20 for full conference. If under a few dollars for API, quality/speed wins. Make provider configurable.
LLM for highlight detection: Claude/OpenAI APIs acceptable. Considered low cost for the requirement.
Video codecs: no specific requirements. Use common, compatible, efficient formats. No need for 4K output.
Audio handling: no special requirements. Content is 99% speech, not hi-fidelity music.
Caption burning: direct text overlay, lower-thirds positioning. Auto-sized and auto-wrapped to fit video window.
Nice-to-have: highlighted word animation as speaker talks (karaoke-style). Not essential, but would enhance captions.
Runtime: Python preferred. No strong user preference, but Python ecosystem stronger for video/ML tooling.
Development machine: Microsoft Surface Book Pro, 32GB RAM, dedicated GPU (laptop-grade, not high-powered). Windows 11.
GPU is laptop-grade, limiting local Whisper performance. May favor API transcription or slower local processing.
Target video editor: DaVinci Resolve. User recently switched and still learning. Exported clips should be easily importable.
DaVinci Resolve compatibility: standard MP4/MOV containers with H.264/H.265 video and AAC audio import seamlessly. Avoid exotic codecs.

exchanges.question: For Lyric Match Mode, walk me through your ideal workflow step-by-step: inputs, matching interface, handling multiple source videos.
exchanges.answer: Input: folder of video files + transcript. Videos often from YouTube (owned). May need preprocessing for transcripts. Want word/phrase clip dictionary approach. Prefer not reusing same source video. Output naming: source filename + clip identifier.

exchanges.question: Dictionary persistence (project vs library), phrase boundary detection method, and match selection criteria.
exchanges.answer: Brand-based persistence spanning multiple projects. Phrase boundaries manually curated and lyrics-driven. Search interface for sourcing phrases. Match selection is human-in-the-loop, phonetic matching nice-to-have.

exchanges.question: Highlights Mode: input setup, topic configuration, and output expectations.
exchanges.answer: Batch process 30+ videos post-conference. Target YouTube/LinkedIn with portrait format. Input includes session description. Output: clip + title/hook. On-screen captions essential with brand-specific emoji/logo injection for mentioned terms.

exchanges.question: User interface model, human-in-the-loop interaction, and project state management.
exchanges.answer: CLI tool. Output dumped to folders for review. Save/resume needed. Must be idempotent and failure-tolerant for unreliable internet.

exchanges.question: Storage format preferences, transcript retention strategy, and video file handling approach.
exchanges.answer: No format preference - use best for use case. Keep full transcripts and videos for future reuse. Videos referenced in place, user copies to brand/source/ structure.

exchanges.question: Transcription provider preferences, LLM for highlight detection, and video processing requirements.
exchanges.answer: Prefer free/cheap, quality matters, speed OK if resumable. Cost estimation needed, ~$20 threshold. Claude/OpenAI for LLM. Standard codecs, speech audio. Direct text overlay captions, lower-thirds, auto-sized. Word highlighting nice-to-have.

exchanges.question: Runtime preference (Node.js vs Python), local machine setup (GPU, RAM, OS), and existing video editing tools.
exchanges.answer: No strong preference, Python seems stronger. Microsoft Surface Book Pro with 32GB RAM and laptop-grade dedicated GPU. Windows 11. Recently moved to DaVinci Resolve, still learning it.
